analysis_metadata.project_name: Light Curve Inversion Pipeline for Asteroid Shape Modeling

repo_files.name: ALCDEF_ALL.zip
repo_files.description: Compressed archive containing 24,643 individual asteroid lightcurve files in ALCDEF pipe-delimited format. Files are named ALCDEF_{number}_{name}.txt where number=0 indicates unnumbered asteroids identified by provisional MPC designation. Contains both dense photometric time-series and metadata blocks with observer, telescope, filter, and geometric information.
repo_files.format: ZIP archive of ALCDEF text files

repo_files.name: MPCORB.DAT.gz
repo_files.description: Gzip-compressed Minor Planet Center orbital element database. Fixed-width format containing orbital elements for all numbered and unnumbered multi-opposition minor planets. Includes absolute magnitude H, slope parameter G, osculating orbital elements (a, e, i, Omega, omega, M), epoch, observation statistics, and asteroid names.

repo_files.name: figures/
repo_files.description: Empty directory designated for output figures including 3D shape renderings, lightcurve fit plots, and validation comparison charts.

repo_files.name: results/
repo_files.description: Directory designated for output results including shape model OBJ files, validation reports, candidate lists, and analysis JSON files.
repo_files.status: being populated (this analysis file is among the first outputs)

repo_files.name: research_rubric.json
repo_files.description: 27-item structured research plan organized into 5 phases: (1) Problem Analysis & Literature Review (6 items), (2) Baseline Implementation & Metrics (5 items), (3) Core Research & Novel Approaches (5 items), (4) Experiments & Evaluation (6 items), (5) Analysis & Documentation (5 items). Currently item_001 is in_progress; all others are pending.

repo_files.name: sources.bib
repo_files.description: Bibliography file for the research project. Currently contains only a header comment; needs population with BibTeX entries for at least 15 papers covering convex inversion, genetic shape optimization, sparse photometry inversion, and survey-based asteroid modeling.

repo_files.name: README.md
repo_files.description: Minimal readme containing only the project title 'asteroid_shapes'. Needs expansion with project description, installation instructions, usage guide, and directory structure.

repo_files.name: .gitattributes
repo_files.description: Git LFS tracking configuration for binary and large data files. Tracks extensions: .gz, .zip, .csv, .obj, .ply, .npz, .tar.gz, .dat, .stl, .h5, .tar, .hdf5, .parquet, .npy, .pickle, .feather, .pkl.

repo_files.name: .gitignore
repo_files.description: Excludes secrets (.env, .key, .pem), Codex/Claude agent metadata (.claude/, .codex/, .archivara/), task logs (TASK_*.md, agent_*.log, orchestration.log), and usage tracking (codex_usage.json).

repo_files.name: TASK_researcher_attempt_1.md
repo_files.description: Agent task log for the researcher's first attempt. Excluded from version control by .gitignore.

alcdef.structure: Pipe-delimited text with metadata/data block pairs
metadata_fields: OBJECTNAME - asteroid name or provisional designation
MPCCODE - Minor Planet Center observatory code
FILTER - photometric filter (C=clear, V, R, SR, GR, etc.)
PABL - phase angle bisector ecliptic longitude (degrees)
PABB - phase angle bisector ecliptic latitude (degrees)
LTCAPP - light-time correction applied (NONE or value)
alcdef.notes: Each file may contain multiple STARTMETADATA/ENDMETADATA blocks representing separate observation sessions of the same asteroid at different epochs. Multiple sessions per file are common for well-observed asteroids.

mpcorb.full_name: Minor Planet Center Orbital Element Database
mpcorb.structure: Fixed-width columns with 43-line header including documentation and column labels

columns.name: designation
columns.description: Packed MPC designation or zero-padded number (e.g., '00001' for Ceres)

columns.name: G
columns.description: Slope parameter for H-G phase function

columns.name: epoch
columns.description: Epoch of osculation (packed MPC date, e.g., K25BL)

columns.name: num_obs
columns.description: Number of observations used in orbit computation

columns.name: arc
columns.description: Arc length (year range or 'N days' for short arcs)

columns.name: perturbations
columns.description: Coarse perturbers (M-v, M-c, M-p, etc.) and hex-encoded precise perturbers

columns.name: computer
columns.description: Name of orbit computer program (e.g., MPCORBFIT, MPCLINUX)

columns.name: asteroid_name
columns.description: Readable asteroid name or provisional designation with discovery date

sections: Section 1: Numbered objects (00001 through 99999, separated by blank lines from other sections)
Section 2: Unnumbered multi-opposition objects with perturbed orbit solutions
Section 3: Recent single-opposition objects with unperturbed orbit solutions

alcdef.file_naming_convention: ALCDEF_{number}_{name}.txt where number=0 for unnumbered asteroids and name is the asteroid name or provisional designation
alcdef.notes: Each file may contain multiple observation sessions (STARTMETADATA/ENDMETADATA blocks) for the same asteroid across different epochs. The number of sessions per file ranges from 1 to over 100 for well-studied asteroids.

mpcorb.notes: Includes all numbered minor planets (1-99999) plus unnumbered multi-opposition and recent single-opposition objects. Data current as of 2026-02-07.

identified_gaps.description: No code has been written yet. The repository contains only data files and configuration. All Python modules for parsing, forward modeling, inversion, optimization, validation, and visualization need to be created from scratch.
identified_gaps.remediation: Implement the full LCI pipeline as a Python package (lci_engine/) with submodules for parsing, forward_model, inversion, ga_optimizer, sparse, validation, and visualization.

identified_gaps.description: No ground-truth shape models have been downloaded. Radar-derived and DAMIT shape models for validation asteroids (Eros, Itokawa, Kleopatra, etc.) are needed as .obj or vertex-facet files for quantitative comparison (Hausdorff distance, IoU).
identified_gaps.remediation: Download .obj shape models from DAMIT (https://astro.troja.mff.cuni.cz/projects/damit/) and/or JPL radar shape models for at least 3 validation targets. Store in results/ directory.

identified_gaps.description: No DAMIT database cross-reference has been performed. A catalog of asteroids with existing published shape models in DAMIT is needed to: (a) identify validation targets with known ground truth, (b) exclude already-modeled asteroids from the new-discovery candidate list, and (c) estimate how many of the 23,743 numbered ALCDEF asteroids lack shape models.
identified_gaps.remediation: Query the DAMIT database (via web API or downloaded catalog) to obtain the list of all asteroids with published shape models. Cross-reference against ALCDEF asteroid numbers.

identified_gaps.description: No sparse photometric data from surveys (Gaia DR3, ZTF, ATLAS, CSS) has been downloaded or integrated. The sparse inversion module (item_013) and hybrid dense+sparse fusion module (item_014) require survey-quality photometry in addition to ALCDEF dense lightcurves.
identified_gaps.remediation: Download sparse photometry from Gaia DR3 Solar System Objects catalog and/or ZTF forced photometry service for selected target asteroids. Alternatively, simulate sparse sampling by subsampling dense ALCDEF data.

identified_gaps.description: The sources.bib file contains only a header comment with no BibTeX entries. At least 15 entries are required covering: Kaasalainen & Torppa 2001 (convex inversion), Bartczak & Dudzinski 2018 (SAGE), Durech et al. 2010 (sparse photometry), Viikinkoski et al. 2015 (ADAM), Cellino et al. 2009 (Gaia photometric inversion), Hapke 1993, Muinonen 1998, and additional papers.
identified_gaps.remediation: Conduct web searches for each key paper and compile BibTeX entries in sources.bib.

identified_gaps.description: No Python package structure, requirements.txt, setup.py/pyproject.toml, or virtual environment configuration exists. Dependencies such as numpy, scipy, astropy, trimesh, matplotlib, and potentially ephemeris libraries (astroquery, jplephem, spiceypy) need to be specified and installed.
identified_gaps.remediation: Create a Python package structure with lci_engine/ directory, __init__.py files, requirements.txt, and pyproject.toml.

identified_gaps.description: Asteroid 6489 Golevka (listed as a validation target in item_007 of the research rubric) is not present in ALCDEF_ALL.zip. An alternative validation target with radar-derived shape must be substituted, or external lightcurve data for Golevka must be obtained from another source.
identified_gaps.remediation: Replace Golevka with an alternative radar-characterized asteroid present in ALCDEF (e.g., 243 Ida, 951 Gaspra, or 1036 Ganymed), or obtain Golevka lightcurves from published literature.

identified_gaps.description: Asteroids 2 Pallas and 253 Mathilde are not present in ALCDEF_ALL.zip. These are well-known asteroids with spacecraft/radar shape data but will need external lightcurve sources if they are to be used for validation.
identified_gaps.remediation: Use alternative well-observed asteroids already in ALCDEF, or obtain Pallas/Mathilde data from published sources or other archives.

identified_gaps.description: Asteroid 25143 Itokawa has only 3 lightcurve sessions and 214 data points in ALCDEF, which may be insufficient for standalone convex inversion. Supplemental data from other archives or sparse survey photometry may be needed to achieve a reliable shape model.
identified_gaps.remediation: Combine ALCDEF data with sparse survey photometry (if available) or acknowledge the limited-data constraint in validation results.

identified_gaps.description: No LCDB (Lightcurve Database) cross-reference is available. Period quality codes (U values) from the LCDB are needed for target selection priority filter P2, which requires U >= 2 to ensure reliable rotation periods.
identified_gaps.remediation: Download the LCDB summary file from http://www.minorplanet.info/lightcurvedatabase.html and cross-reference asteroid numbers to obtain period and U-code values.

validation_targets.description: Asteroids with known shape models (from radar, spacecraft, or DAMIT) that exist in ALCDEF and can be used for blind validation testing of the inversion pipeline

asteroids.name: Eros
asteroids.suitability: excellent - dense data, well-characterized ground truth from spacecraft encounter, elongated shape provides strong lightcurve amplitude

asteroids.name: Itokawa
asteroids.suitability: moderate - limited ALCDEF data (only 3 sessions) but excellent ground truth from spacecraft; contact binary shape is a strong test for non-convex GA module

asteroids.name: Kleopatra
asteroids.suitability: excellent - highly non-convex dumbbell/dog-bone shape, dense data, strong test for whether GA can recover extreme concavities

asteroids.name: Betulia
asteroids.suitability: moderate - irregular shape with modest data, useful as a secondary validation target

asteroids.name: Golevka
asteroids.suitability: unavailable - not present in ALCDEF archive; must use alternative target or obtain external data

additional_spacecraft_visited_asteroids_.description: Asteroids visited by spacecraft that are present in ALCDEF and could serve as supplementary validation targets

asteroids.name: Ceres
asteroids.notes: Nearly spherical, low lightcurve amplitude - limited shape information from photometry alone

asteroids.name: Vesta
asteroids.notes: Large south-pole basin creates detectable non-convexity signal

asteroids.name: Ida
asteroids.notes: Elongated S-type asteroid with satellite Dactyl

asteroids.name: Gaspra
asteroids.notes: Irregular angular shape, limited ALCDEF coverage

high_data_volume_asteroids.description: Asteroids in ALCDEF with the richest observational coverage, suitable for dense-data convex inversion as primary new-discovery candidates

asteroids.name: Ganymed
asteroids.notes: Most data points of any asteroid, NEO

asteroids.name: Glauke
asteroids.notes: Highest session count of all asteroids

candidate_discovery_pool.description: Summary statistics for identifying asteroids without existing shape models that have sufficient data for new inversion
candidate_discovery_pool.estimated_asteroids_in_damit: approximately 3000 as of 2025 per DAMIT database statistics
candidate_discovery_pool.estimated_candidates_not_in_damit: approximately 20000 or more numbered asteroids in ALCDEF not yet in DAMIT
filtering_criteria_for_top_candidates: P1: NEO flag or estimated diameter > 100 km (from MPCORB H-magnitude assuming geometric albedo 0.1-0.25 and D = 1329 / sqrt(albedo) * 10^(-H/5) km)
P2: Period quality U >= 2 from LCDB cross-reference or ALCDEF metadata quality flags
P3: Not already in DAMIT (requires cross-reference query against DAMIT catalog)
P4: Sufficient data: >= 20 lightcurve sessions in ALCDEF spanning >= 3 apparitions, or >= 100 sparse survey data points over >= 3 apparitions
next_steps: Parse all 24,643 ALCDEF files to build a complete catalog with session counts, date ranges, filters used, and data point counts per asteroid
Cross-reference against DAMIT database to identify asteroids without published shape models
Cross-reference against LCDB for period quality codes
Compute estimated diameters from MPCORB H-magnitudes
Apply priority filters and rank candidates

mpcorb_coverage.overlap_with_alcdef: All 23,743 numbered asteroids in ALCDEF are expected to have orbital elements in MPCORB since MPCORB contains all 99,999 numbered objects. The 890 unnumbered ALCDEF asteroids can be matched via packed MPC designation.
utility_for_inversion: Provides osculating orbital elements (a, e, i, Omega, omega, M, epoch) needed to compute Sun-asteroid-observer geometry vectors at any epoch via two-body or n-body propagation
H and G parameters enable absolute magnitude calibration and phase function correction for sparse photometry
Arc length and observation count provide data quality indicators
Semi-major axis and eccentricity identify NEOs (a < 1.3 AU, q < 1.3 AU) for priority filtering
